Time to check in on my Japanese progress!
Unfortunately since I am now hitting the WaniKani “Hill of difficulty” at Level 5, which means that level ups will only ever take longer to complete now. This is where most people start quitting.
As an illustration, here’s a graph that depicts the workload that WaniKani has based on levels:
As you can see, this workload will keep increasing until level 20, and then plateau. But that doesn’t mean stagnation! It’s simply an indicator that the workload will stay enormously high for a while.
WaniKani Progress My current WaniKani revision progress can be shown in this picture: I am hovering around a ~90% retention rate on average.
Dropping Anki I have decided to stop using Anki for vocabulary for now, for the following reasons:
SRS Overload As WaniKani is already an SRS, using Anki leads to redundancy and information overload, as I am studying 15 new words per day at the maximum.
Time constraints As I’m now approaching my final semester at university, I also have to come to terms with being extremely busy with my thesis and not having enough time to do WaniKani and Anki at the same time
Anki Syncing I own two computers and a phone, all with Anki installed. Syncing progress between the three is not automatic, and I end up revising words I already revised multiple times, that leads to progress stagnation and I’m better off first finishing WaniKani, then Anki.
Thanks for reading, see you at the next language-learning check-in!

The Beauty of Non-Commutativity To many, the Rubik’s cube may seem like a puzzle, requiring black magic to solve. However, learning that it represents one of the most fascinating non-abelian groups in recreational mathematics, widens our understanding about how this fantastic puzzle works. Unlike simple rotations or basic arithmetic where order doesn’t matter (2+3 = 3+2), the Rubik’s cube exhibits a fundamental property: the order of operations matters.
The Group Structure The Rubik’s cube perfectly embodies the four axioms of group theory while demonstrating non-abelian properties:
Closure: Any sequence of moves produces another valid cube state Associativity: (RU)R’ = R(UR’) holds true Identity: The solved state serves as our identity element Inverse: Each move has a corresponding inverse (R and R') Non-Commutativity: RU ‚â† UR (the defining property of non-abelian groups) Subgroups and Decomposition Within the massive group of all possible cube states (8!√ó3‚Å∏-1 √ó 12!√ó2¬π¬π-1 = 43,252,003,274,489,856,000), we find numerous interesting subgroups. The most practical for speedsolving are the conjugate subgroups and commutators.
Conjugates in Action A conjugate follows the pattern ABA’, where A’ is the inverse of A. Common examples in speedsolving:
Sexy Move: (RUR'U') U-Perm: (R2 U)(RUR'U')(R'U'R2) Commutators Commutators take the form [A,B] = ABA’B’. They’re essential for:
Corner permutations Edge orientation Center piece manipulation Practical Applications Understanding the non-abelian nature of the cube group improves solving efficiency:
Recognition of equivalent sequences Algorithm optimization Intuitive solving techniques Algorithm Group Theory Interpretation T-Perm Conjugate of 3-cycle Y-Perm Double commutator R-Perm Conjugated 4-cycle Beyond the Basics The group theory of the Rubik’s cube extends into:
Permutation groups Symmetry groups Quaternion groups This mathematical framework doesn’t just satisfy academic curiosity - it directly translates to faster solving times and deeper understanding of the puzzle’s mechanics.
*Note: This post assumes basic familiarity with cube notation (R, U, F, etc.). For notation guidance, check out This guide

The Schwarzschild Radius, the black hole warning sign The Schwarzschild radius‚Äînamed after Karl Schwarzschild‚Äîis a cornerstone in Einstein’s general theory of relativity. It defines the point where our perception of physics and reality no longer follow their usual laws, the point of no return, where nothing‚Äînot even light‚Äîcan escape.
Let’s dive into one of my favorite topics when it comes to black holes!
What Is the Schwarzschild Radius? The Schwarzschild radius is the radius from the center of mass where the escape velocity of an object equals the speed of light (~1,079,252,848.8 km/h!). This means nothing can escape it. Any object crossing this radius is lost to the black hole, as no information or matter can escape its grip.
The Schwarzschild radius of Earth‚Äîif we were to condense it into a black hole‚Äîwould be 8.87 millimeters, showing how dense the object has to be.
The Math Behind It To calculate the Schwarzschild radius, we start with the escape velocity formula:
$$ v_e = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{r}} $$
Here:
$v_e$: Escape velocity $\left(\frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}\right)$, $G$: Gravitational constant $\left(\approx 6.674 \times 10^{-11} \frac{\text{m}^3}{\text{kg} \cdot \text{s}^2}\right)$, $M$: Mass of the object (kg), $r$: Distance from the center (m). Velocity equals the speed of light $c$ ($ \approx 3 \times 10^8$ m/s). Substituting $v_e = c$ and solving for $r$:
$$ R_s = \frac{2GM}{c^2} $$
The Schwarzschild radius depends only on the mass $M$ of the object, showing that even a small object can theoretically have a Schwarzschild radius if compressed enough.
Implications and Observations Even more than being a curious constant, it marks the event horizon, which is the beyond where physics and reality warp beyond our current understanding. Since general relativity tells us that spacetime can curve infinitely, nothing will ever escape a black hole.
The observation of an object near a black hole is not fully understood, but we understand that the obejct will never fully enter the black hole from out perspective, but appear to slow down, and even stay still before the event horizon.
The next time you look up, try thinking about how much cool stuff is out there - both literally and mathematically!

Time to Check in on my Japanese Progress!
To preface this series of posts for the next.. I don’t know.. 4-5 months? I’ll be doing an update once a week, reviewing my Anki card progress, that is, how many cards I know and how much my vocabulary has grown, alongside my WaniKani Progress, which is my Kanji learning method.
Well then.. Ë°å„Åì„ÅÜ!
For starters, I am currently on level 4 on WaniKani, which will cover about 30% of the vocab found on sites such as NHK Easy which have simplified Japanese news articles, aimed at aiding those still learning Japanese.
What do the level in WaniKani mean? WaniKani has split Kanji groups into different levels, ranked per difficulty, frequency, and scenarios.
I am aiming for around 90% comprehension, for a first milestone, which is around level 24, so on average, that will take 25-30 weeks.
The levels also cover the amount of Kanji needed for each of the JLPT levels. The following is how much the first 27 levels cover
Where am I at? Anki Progress My current status in Anki shows that I have about 300 words learned/in progress, out of 11,000ish. That is still a ways way away, but I firmly believe I can get this number within 1-2 years.
A mature word is one I’ve gotten right a lot, and is basically “memorized”, learning words are ones I’ve reviewed within the past week or two, which aren’t matured yet.
WaniKani Progress As mentioned, I am currently on level 4 on WaniKani with 89 Kanjis learned and 173 words. Seems like my retention rate is floating around 90% which is not too bad (for my memory standards)
Final remarks I think it’s important to enjoy the game-ification aspect of WaniKani, but to remember not to speed through it. The faster you try to learn the words, without reviewing the previous ones correctly , the more words will stack up for reviewing. even now I’m at 100 reviews per day! Imagine once I reach level 20-30, those might be up to 1000 reviews if I don’t consistently review and review correctly
Thanks for reading, see you at the next language-learning check-in!

content:
As of January 2025, I’ve been learning Japanese for more than a month, after picking it up twice in the last 3 years, and then leaving it due to being busy. This year is different, I will try my absolute hardest in order to reach a level I am satisfied with.
Well.. where do we start?
Methodology I’ll be using the Refold method, which mainly focuses on immersion.
What is immersion? Immersion is a technique in which you consume media in your target language.
The key here is that this input should be just above your skill (This is a highly debated topic! Some people say it can be any level)
Immersing media can be anything from Music, TV shows, Movies, Podcasts, Books, and so on..
So, how does the roadmap look like? The refold method puts big emphasis on immersion, but also vocabulary. Grammar is also important of course, but thought of as a lesser goal, due to native speakers picking it up naturally
üí° Think about it, how did you learn the Grammar of your Native language, or even english? I personally picked it up naturally through watching thousands and thousand of hours of TV/Videos The point is that Grammar, while learnable from books, is something you get used to over time.
Step 1: Acquire Vocabulary This will have an entire blog post on it’s own, but according to Zipf’s there’s a set number of words that are used in 95% of the language. For most languages that peaks around 3-5 thousand words (For english it’s 2000 words for 90% of speech).
‚ÑπÔ∏è Research shows that the most frequent:
1,000 words cover ~75% of daily conversation 2,200 words cover ~90% of general content 3,500 words reach ~95% comprehension 5,000 words give you ~98% coverage How do I learn vocabulary? However you like! There are methods loved by language learners, such as Anki which give you daily reviews of already learned vocab, and give you 10-20 new words per day to learn, which means you’ll learn 5000 words in just about 2 years.
Now 5000 words is nowhere near enough to understand native content (that is more like 15-25k words) without help, but we can understand most things with a little help!
Step 2: Immerse, Immerse, Immerse The Moe Way is loved by many and has extensive Anki setup guides and immersing techniques.
Immersing is a very subjective aspect, if you like anime, then watch anime. If you like music, then download all the J-POP you like! If you’re into J-Dramas, then watch those!
Just remember that you have to somewhat understand the input at least slightly, or if it’s too high level it’s a good time to start getting used to how the language sounds, to be able to follow it.
Step 3: Learn Grammar for every few milestones I would personally learn Grammar, and then learn a Grammar point I encounter that I don’t know. There are sites such as BunPro that let you choose different grammar sources!
My Personal Goals for 2025 Q1 (January - March)
Master first 1,000 core vocabulary words Complete basic grammar (N5 level) Daily immersion: 1 hour minimum Q2 (April - June)
Reach 2,000 vocabulary words Start reading simple manga with furigana Increase immersion to 2 hours daily Q3 (July - September)
Build vocabulary to 3,000 words Begin consuming media (anime, youtube videos, music) without subtitles Finish Tae Kim’s Japanese Grammar Guide Q4 (October - December)
Reach 4,000 vocabulary words Attempt N4 JLPT exam Regular conversation practice ‚ö†Ô∏è Remember: These goals are ambitious! I am a student with a LOT of free time, so if the timeframe for you looks different, do not disparage! Tools I’ll Be Using Anki
Core 2k/6k deck for vocabulary Review time: 30 minutes daily Immersion Sources
Netflix Japanese content (Double subtitles) YouTube channels (recommend some good ones?) NHK Easy News Japanese podcasts for beginners (Hello Japan is a good one :-) ) Grammar Resources
Tae Kim’s Grammar Guide Japanese From Zero series WaniKani
Amazing resource for learning Kanji Free for the first month, then 9$/month Helps build your vocabulary as well as kanji recognition via mnemonics Progress Tracking I’ll be posting a few times a month with the following:
Number of words learned (tracked through Anki) Hours of immersion Comprehension improvements (How much of a setnence do i understand on my own?) Challenges faced (Will need an entire blog for that to be honest x.x ) Resources discovered Next Steps In my next post, I’ll dive deeper into setting up an effective Anki system and share my favorite immersion resources. Stay tuned!
What are your language learning goals for 2025? Share in the comments below!
